metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Heirs and Legal Representatives of Amarchand N. Shroff

facts.text: Amarchand N. Shroff, Mangaldas and Hiralal were partners in a firm of solicitors.
Thereafter the partnership was carried on by Mangaldas and Hiralal up to November 30, 1949.
On December 1, 1949, Ramesh son of Amarchand joined the firm as the third partner.

Arrangement between partners for realisations of old outstandings: in respect of work done up to death of Amarchand, divided amongst Amarchand, Mangaldas and Hiralal; work between July 8, 1949 and November 30, 1949 between Mangaldas and Hiralal; work after December 1, 1949 amongst Mangaldas, Hiralal and Ramesh.
The firm kept its accounts on cash basis.
For assessment years 1950-51 to 1954-55, amounts received by heirs of Amarchand: Rs. 37,847/-, Rs. 43,162/-, Rs. 34,899/-, Rs. 13,402/- and Rs. 32,523/- out of outstandings.
Income-tax Officer sought to tax these realisations; for 1950-51 and 1951-52 assessed in hands of heirs as Hindu undivided family.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Appellate Tribunal; Tribunal held amounts not income of HUF but inheritance or realisations of assets of Amarchand.
Revenue started proceedings u/s 34 on Amarchand by his heirs as individual.
Assessments made u/s 34 r/w s.24B for 1950-51 to 1954-55.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner held notice u/s 34 valid only for 1950-51, quashed others; Commissioner appealed to Tribunal.
Tribunal held no assessment on Amarchand, s.24B not applicable to income after death, capital receipt.
High Court answered reference question in negative: sums not assessable u/s 24B.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 37,847/-, Rs. 43,162/-, Rs. 34,899/-, Rs. 13,402/-, and Rs. 32,523/- were assessable to income-tax in the hands of the assessee Amarchand N. Shroff by his legal heirs and representatives in the five respective years under reference?
Interpretation of s.24B of the Income-tax Act: whether amounts received by heirs after death deemed income of deceased.

petitioner_arguments.text: On a correct interpretation of s.24B, amounts received by heirs after death deemed by fiction in sub-s.(1) to be income received by Amarchand and liable to tax; heirs liable out of estate as deceased would have been if alive. Emphasis on 'or any tax which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died'.

respondent_arguments.text: Amounts not taxable apart from s.24B, which has no application; capital receipts, not income.

court_reasoning.text: All sub-sections of s.24B to be read together; sub-s.(1) confined to cases in sub-ss.(2) and (3): income received by deceased before death or by heirs after death but in previous year of death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by legal representatives in years succeeding the previous year in which deceased died.

court_reasoning.text: Firm on cash basis; assessee ordinarily living person; s.24B extends legal personality only for previous year of death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income received subsequent to previous year of death not assessable as deceased's income.

court_reasoning.text: Fiction in s.24B limited to purpose: tax income received in lifetime or by heirs in same previous year; cannot extend beyond.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legal fictions limited to purpose for which created.

holdings.text: The amounts received by heirs in assessment years 1950-51 to 1954-55 not assessable as income of Amarchand u/s 24B.
s.24B applies only to income of previous year in which deceased dies, not subsequent years.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of words 'if he had not died'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: No assessment after death without s.24B; lacuna filled by s.24B limited to previous year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Additional Income-tax Officer v. E. Alfred
precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of Act; does not support taxing post-death receipts beyond previous year.
Assessee alive when income received; s.24B inapplicable.
Amount received in same previous year as death.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment on living person for previous year income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Legal fictions limited to purpose created.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.24B governs tax on deceased's estate by representatives, limited to previous year of death; invoked for assessment of post-death realizations.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; High Court rightly answered reference in negative; amounts not assessable u/s 24B in hands of legal heirs.

key_quotes.text: "Section 24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of s.24B.

key_quotes.text: "By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should not be extended beyond that legitimate field."
key_quotes.speaker: court
